fr:mainmatter.html:p: An additive functor F : \mathcal {A} \to \mathcal {B} is effaceable iff for each object X in \mathcal {A}, there exists a monomorphism X \to I whose image under F is zero. Dually, it is coeffaceable iff for each object X there exists an epimorphism P \to X whose image under F is zero.

Homology H_\bullet as a functor from the category of chain complexes (bounded from below) of \mathcal {A} to \mathcal {A} is a homological universal \delta -functor. Dually, cohomology is a cohomological universal \delta -functor.

Every chain complex injects into its cone, whose cohomology is zero. So cohomology is effaceable. Dually every chain complex is a quotient of its cocone, hence homology is coeffaceable. Therefore by Theorem we finish the proof.

Given a cohomological \delta -functor T^\bullet , if each T^n for n > 0 is effaceable, then it is a universal \delta -functor. Dually, if a homological \delta -functor is coeffaceable, then it is universal.

Given an object X, consider the exact sequence given by effaceability 0 \longrightarrow X \longrightarrow I \longrightarrow Y \longrightarrow 0. Then we have a long exact sequence 0 \to T^0 X \to T^0 I \to T^0 Y \xrightarrow {\delta } T^1 X \xrightarrow {0} T^1 I. and the rest breaks into infinitely many short exact sequences 0 \to T^{n+1} I \to T^{n+1} Y \to T^{n+2} X \to 0.

For independence, we first prove that if two effacements X \to I, X \to I' are connected by a morphism I \to I', then the resulting transformations are equal. This is essentially the same as the proof of naturality, except \varphi is replaced with \textrm {id}. Now any two effacements are connected by a zigzag, since we can take the diagonal X \to I \times I' and project out.
Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal {C} \to \mathcal {D} between them, the following are equivalent. In this case, we call the functor additive.

html:ul.html:li: The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{\mathcal {C}}(X, Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf {Ab}-enriched functor.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of F, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel {\sim \,}{\to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that F preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
